summary: Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cells of the cervix, the lower, narrow end of the uterus. It typically develops slowly from precancerous changes called cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) over 10 to 20 years, often without early symptoms. Almost all cases are caused by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV). It is the fourth-most common cancer and cause of cancer death in women globally, with higher incidence and mortality in low- and middle-income countries.
causes: Long-lasting infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV)
Integration of high-risk HPV DNA into host genome
HPV viral proteins E6 and E7 inducing cancer
HPV E6 protein degrading tumor suppressor protein p53
HPV E7 protein degrading and inactivating tumor suppressor protein pRb
Loss of p53 and pRb leading to increased blood vessel growth (VEGF over-expression), loss of tumor cell suppression, and cell cycle regulation disruptions
risk_factors: Weakened immune system (e.g., due to HIV, immunosuppressant medications)
Multiple pregnancies (especially seven or more full-term pregnancies)
Starting sex at a young age
Having many sexual partners or partners with many sexual partners
symptoms: Abnormal vaginal bleeding (after sex, between menstrual periods, after douching, after pelvic exam, heavy bleeding)
Vaginal discharge (watery, strong odor, contains blood)
Leakage of urine or faeces from the vagina (rare)
Hydronephrosis with flank pain (due to blocked ureters)
Blood clots in legs (due to blocked pelvic veins)
diagnosis: Medical history and family health history review
Colposcopy (magnified visual inspection of cervix, often with acetic acid and Lugol's iodine staining)
Cervical biopsy (tissue sample removal for microscopic examination, e.g., punch biopsy)
Loop electrical excision procedure (LEEP) (for severe precancerous lesions)
Cervical conization (cone biopsy) (for severe precancerous lesions or diagnosis)
Medical imaging (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) to check for tumor spread or alternative diseases
treatments: Surgery (excision, ablation, hysterectomy, radical hysterectomy, trachelectomy, exenteration)
Chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin-based chemotherapy, combination of hycamtin and cisplatin)
Immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors: pembrolizumab (Keytruda), cemiplimab-rwlc (Libtayo), Tisotumab vedotin (Tivdak))
HPV vaccination (as a primary prevention measure, also reduces risk of cancerous changes)
related_genes: TP53 (gene for tumor suppressor protein p53)
RB1 (gene for tumor suppressor protein pRb)
VEGFA (gene for vascular endothelial growth factor, associated with over-expression)
